docs.lead_paragraph: Cocaine users face a newly discovered and possibly fatal risk: coronary aneurysms, a ballooning of the walls of coronary arteries. The condition increases the chance of suffering a heart attack, even years after users stop the drug, researchers in Minnesota are reporting. The risk of developing an aneurysm was four times as high among cocaine users in their mid-40's as among nonusers in the same age group, according to the study, reported yesterday in the journal Circulation, which is published by the American Heart Association.

headline.main: Cocaine Users Face Greater Risk of Aneurysm

docs.snippet: Cocaine users face a newly discovered and possibly fatal risk: coronary aneurysms, a ballooning of the walls of coronary arteries.

docs.lead_paragraph: Current health care etiquette requires that a patient be viewed as a consumer, a knowledgeable care partner who is equipped and ready to take charge. The notion makes some sense; after all, who cares more about your health than you do? But in this global therapeutic village where the customer is king, a simple question remains unanswered: What happens if something goes awry, if a decision shared or even directed by a patient turns out to be the wrong one? On whose desk does that buck stop?

headline.main: Doctors Do Know Things Patients Don't Know

docs.snippet: If you choose the wrong path, is your guide to blame?

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study reports that regular use of acetaminophen, the pain reliever sold under the name Tylenol, may be associated with a higher risk of asthma and other lung problems. ''Evidence is beginning to emerge about the potentially harmful effects of consistent use of acetaminophen on respiratory health,'' the authors write in The American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine.
docs.snippet: A new study reports that regular use of acetaminophen, the pain reliever sold under the name Tylenol, may be associated with a higher risk of asthma and other lung problems.

docs.lead_paragraph: Men who associate alcohol with sexual desire can become sexually stimulated just by being unconsciously exposed to words related to drinking, researchers say. Writing in the journal Addiction, researchers said the findings offered more evidence about the power of memory when it came to alcohol. Other studies have found that people who wrongly believe they have been given alcohol can exhibit the effects of drinking.
docs.snippet: Men who associate alcohol with sexual desire can become sexually stimulated just by being unconsciously exposed to words related to drinking, researchers say.

docs.lead_paragraph: Polyunsaturated vegetable oils from plants like soybeans and sunflowers are generally praised by nutritionists because they help people keep their cholesterol down and, it is believed, avoid heart disease. But a new study reports that when used to fry foods, the oils produce a toxic compound that has been associated with a variety of illnesses, including cardiovascular disease, Parkinson's and Alzheimer's diseases, and liver problems.

headline.main: Healthful Oil Can Become a Threat

docs.snippet: A new study reports that when used to fry foods, polyunsaturated vegetable oils produce a toxic compound.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last June, a 4-year-old boy in South Carolina was hospitalized for five days with a fever of 105, watery diarrhea and abdominal cramping. The doctors quickly found the cause: his stool contained Salmonella typhimurium, a common bacterial infection often caused by eating undercooked chicken or by handling reptiles.

headline.main: Salmonella Outbreak Traced to Pet Rodents

docs.snippet: The cases occurred in 10 states from December 2003 to the fall of 2004.

docs.lead_paragraph: The little old lady with the fine white hair and the sky-blue raincoat was there every day, sitting on a couch in the lobby of our apartment building. I remembered her from the time before her brain began to shred. We'd meet and nod hello in the elevator, but back then I paid no more attention to her than to most of the other tenants who came and went in our busy building.

headline.main: Old, Afraid And Gripped By Demons

docs.snippet: Does everyone harbor a similar beast buried deep in the brain?

docs.lead_paragraph: Last month, when the champion American cyclist Tyler Hamilton was accused of blood doping, or transfusing himself with another person's blood to increase his oxygen-carrying red cells, he offered a surprising defense: the small amount of different blood found mixed in with his own must have come from a ''vanishing twin.'' In other words, his scientific expert argued, Mr. Hamilton had a twin that died in utero but, before dying, contributed some blood cells to him during fetal life. And those cells remained in his body, producing blood that matched the dead twin and not Mr. Hamilton. Or perhaps it was his mother's blood that got mixed in during fetal life.

headline.main: Cheating, Or an Early Mingling Of the Blood?

docs.snippet: Did the genetic legacy of a "vanishing twin" cause the champion cyclist Tyler Hamilton to test positive for doping?

docs.lead_paragraph: Public service announcements by celebrities urging people to get cancer screening tests may be admirable, but are they desirable? Not really, a new study argues.
docs.snippet: Are public service announcements by celebrities urging people to get cancer screening tests desirable? Not really, a new study argues.

docs.lead_paragraph: Not all that long ago, a low cholesterol score was seen as a sign of relative good health and a low risk of heart disease. But increasingly, doctors are identifying a group of people whose levels of L.D.L, the so-called bad cholesterol, are low, but who still appear to be at increased risk for atherosclerosis, heart attack and stroke.

headline.main: Low Cholesterol? Don't Brag Quite Yet

docs.snippet: Why some people with low cholesterol may still be at risk for heart disease.
